text:
>A lot of HS devs have not used version control systems or have not used git in a long time and feel rusty. I want to make it painless.

definitely in that category...when you see my profile just try not to laugh. I even went searching for how to update the logo (which I thought would be easy) and ended up not being able to sort it out. Do I need to be a collaborator?

The easiest way is to fork the project, which will allow you to make any changes you want in a safe space, then when you’re done making your changes you click the “new pull request” button on GitHub. and it will ask you what branch you want to merge with and that would be the master branch of the main crankshaft repo.
You do not need to be a collaborator, in-fact I learned there are cons to being a collaborator
if you contribute often I will make you one though

Basically collaborator status means you can commit directly to the branches in the main repo. increasing the chance of dealing with merge conflicts, and if the collaborators aren’t careful and mindful and keep to a process, it’s easy to cause mistakes.(mistakes can almost always be corrected, but the advantage of working in a fork, is you’re not going to experience those same issues)
Plus if you feel you want to start fresh, you can blow away your fork and re-fork the main repo at any time
and to clarify you do not need to be a collaborator to show up as a contributor. Everyone will still see you added code, so you get full credit
thanks for the breakdown!
and lol when I see your profile photo I’m expecting a sombrero and moustache now lol
it isn't but I should update it!!
lol
inb4 inspirational words from Dana Holdt

yo - working on  grid things and my brain is failing me on to mustache or not to mustache when setting variables....
`{% set colwidth = (100/{{columnCount}}) * i  %}` --- to mustache `columnCount` or not to mustache. this is the question....
<@U7SL518D6> if you were hoping for inspirational... my brain is not the place :stuck_out_tongue:
hahaha
also -- that a11y <dialog> shenanigans is a nice find
so you would NOT moustache in this case
That's what I thought
....heading back to VS now to correct the errs of my ways....

totally agree on the dialog one. Another element I plan to implement a native version of in the framework is `<details><summary></summary></details>`
Example of what it’s for:
<https://designers.HubSpot.com/code-gallery/entry/founders/TheWebTech-HS-Accessible-FAQ-Module?hsLang=en>
I'm thinking I might tackle converting that guy to a very basic module element. How are you going about doing the testing for the additions of the variables and other shenanigans?
I'm working on getting a variable count grid going right now, but obviously this is living locally only and I'm not truly sure how you're integrating all of this into the Github Pages
Read As: I've never used Github Pages :slightly_smiling_face:

so to clarify, the github pages does not use the framework itself. It’s using a github pages starter theme.

We haven’t really discussed thoroughly how examples will be shown, I do expect I’ll have a dev portal open for it which we can link over to for demos of things in action. Code samples will be added to the docs. The docs site is all markdown based so it’s easy to add copyable code blocks
ideally over time it’d be great to have the docs site and example site be the same but alas I don’t have $300/month to throw at it(need to have HubL get executed for the framework to work.)
Yeah... that cost point is a bit problematic.

Yea, something I’ve been considering for the framework is allowing companies to sponsor in exchange for their logo added.

Then also reaching out to HS devs to see if HS would be willing to “sponsor” a paid dev portal basically
get that tesla owner to pay for it :slightly_smiling_face:
this could be founded by the fund that you mentioned where supporting agencies can help contributing
and you know who you are
